item.title: UFO (British TV series)
item.description:
UFO (British TV series) ðŸ”—

A British science fiction television series that aired from 1970 to 1971, focusing on Earth’s defense against an alien invasion in the then-future of 1980.

Premise ðŸ”—

In 1980, Earth is under threat from aliens from a dying planet who are abducting humans for their organs. SHADO (Supreme Headquarters Alien Defence Organisation), a secret international military agency operating under the guise of a movie studio, is formed to defend Earth. SHADO utilizes advanced technology, including a space intruder detection satellite (SID), lunar interceptors, a submarine/aircraft called Skydiver, and ground-based SHADO Mobiles. The aliens are humanoid, requiring a green oxygenated liquid and special contact lenses. Their UFOs can travel faster than light but have limited time in Earth’s atmosphere.

Cast and characters ðŸ”—

The series features a large ensemble cast with frequent changes. Ed Bishop as Commander Ed Straker is the only actor to appear in every episode.

Main characters ðŸ”—

  • Commander Edward Straker (Ed Bishop): The head of SHADO, posing as the head of Harlington-Straker Film Studios.
  • Colonel Paul Foster (Michael Billington): A former test pilot recruited into SHADO.
  • Lieutenant Gay Ellis (Gabrielle Drake): Moonbase commander.
  • Colonel Alec Freeman (George Sewell): SHADO’s second-in-command.
  • General James Henderson (Grant Taylor): Straker’s superior and president of the International Astrophysical Commission.
  • Colonel Virginia Lake (Wanda Ventham): A SHADO operative who later becomes first officer.
  • Captain Peter Carlin (Peter Gordeno): First commander of Skydiver.
  • Lieutenant Nina Barry (Dolores Mantez): Moonbase operative.
  • Captain Lew Waterman (Gary Myers): Second commander of Skydiver.
  • Lieutenant Keith Ford (Keith Alexander): Communications officer.
  • Lieutenant Ayshea Johnson (Ayshea Brough): SHADO headquarters officer.
  • Doctor Douglas Jackson (Vladek Sheybal): SHADO psychiatrist and science officer.
  • Lieutenant Joan Harrington (Antonia Ellis): Moonbase operative.
  • Miss Ealand (Norma Ronald): Straker’s secretary.
  • Lieutenant Mark Bradley (Harry Baird): Interceptor pilot.

Minor characters ðŸ”—

Shakira Baksh (later Michael Caine’s wife) played Joanna, a Moonbase operative. Steven Berkoff played Interceptor pilot Steve Minto, and Georgina Moon played Lieutenant Sylvia Howell.

Episodes ðŸ”—

The 26 episodes were broadcast in a non-chronological order by ITV. The list provides the original ATV (Midlands) broadcast order, along with director, writer, original air date, and production code. Episode titles include “Identified,” “Exposed,” “The Cat with Ten Lives,” “Conflict,” “A Question of Priorities,” and “The Long Sleep.”

Alternative viewing orders ðŸ”—

Different viewing orders exist, including production order, ATV broadcast order, and recommended orders by UFO Series, Fanderson, and ITC. A table compares these different orders.

Production ðŸ”—

Lew Grade approached Gerry Anderson to create a live-action TV series, resulting in UFO. The series was influenced by UFO sightings and Christiaan Barnard’s transplant operations. Sylvia Anderson designed the costumes, including the purple wigs for female Moonbase staff. The Harlington-Straker Studio was the actual studio where the series was filmed.

Filming ðŸ”—

Filming began in April 1969 at MGM-British Studios, then moved to Pinewood Studios in June 1970. George Sewell and Gabrielle Drake left after the studio change. Harry Baird and Peter Gordeno also left the series.

Costumes ðŸ”—

Female Moonbase personnel wore purple wigs, silver catsuits, and heavy eye makeup for a futuristic look. Ed Bishop initially bleached his hair, then wore a white wig. Other male characters also wore wigs. Only two alien suits were made.

Special effects ðŸ”—

Derek Meddings supervised the special effects, using techniques like double-walled visors and underwater effects.

Vehicle design ðŸ”—

Derek Meddings and Mike Trim designed the vehicles. The gull-winged cars were originally built for DoppelgÃ¤nger. The blue SHADO Jeeps were built on Mini Moke chassis. Few original props and miniatures have survived.

Broadcast ðŸ”—

Broadcasters were unsure if UFO was for adults or children. In the UK, episodes were shown in the late afternoon and Saturday mornings.

Reception ðŸ”—

Reviews of UFO are mixed. Some praise the visuals, music, and costumes, while others criticize the writing and pacing. Some reviews note the series’ mix of adult themes and science fiction elements.

Aborted second series ðŸ”—

ITC commissioned a second series, UFO 2, set entirely on the Moon. However, when ratings dropped, ITC cancelled the plans. Gerry Anderson then created Space: 1999 from the pre-production work.

Merchandise ðŸ”—

The series generated a range of toys, including Dinky die-cast vehicles.

Compilation films ðŸ”—

Several episodes were compiled into films, including Invasion: UFO. Italian producers also created compilation films with mixed reviews.

Home media ðŸ”—

Channel 5 and ITC released VHS collections. The complete series was released on DVD in 2002.

Proposed feature film ðŸ”—

In 2009, a feature film adaptation was announced, but it did not enter production.

In other media ðŸ”—

Stories set in the UFO universe have appeared in novels, comics, and video games. Julian Gollop cited UFO as an influence for UFO: Enemy Unknown. Yoshiyuki Sadamoto drew inspiration from UFO for character designs in Neon Genesis Evangelion.

Translations ðŸ”—

The series has been translated into French, German, Japanese, Italian, Spanish, and Brazilian Portuguese.

item.title: Alien Nation
item.description:
Alien Nation ðŸ”—

Alien Nation is an American science fiction media franchise created by Rockne S. O’Bannon, known for Farscape. The franchise, owned by 20th Century Studios, encompasses film, television, novels, and comics centered around alien refugees living on Earth. It blends science fiction with elements of drama, police procedural, and buddy cop genres.

Setting ðŸ”—

The franchise is set in the near future in the United States, specifically starting in 1991. A flying saucer crashes in the Mojave Desert, revealing the Tenctonese, an extraterrestrial race referred to as “Newcomers.” These aliens are escaping slavery from a cruel Overseer race. The Tenctonese resemble humans but possess anatomical differences and enhanced physical and intellectual capabilities due to selective breeding. The core concept revolves around the Newcomers’ integration into American society, exploring themes of multiculturalism and acceptance.

Film ðŸ”—

The franchise began with the 1988 film Alien Nation, released by 20th Century Fox. The film depicts the integration of the Tenctonese refugees, or Newcomers, into human society in Los Angeles. It combines science fiction and police drama elements. The film stars Mandy Patinkin as Sam “George” Francisco, a Newcomer detective in the Los Angeles Police Department, and James Caan as Matthew Sykes, his initially reluctant human partner.

Television ðŸ”—

In 1989, Fox adapted the film into a television series, also called Alien Nation. The series follows the same premise as the film, focusing on the Newcomers’ integration after their ship crashes on Earth. Eric Pierpoint stars as George Francisco, and Gary Graham as Matthew Sikes. The series explores themes of racism and the treatment of minority ethnic groups. The series ran for one season of 21 episodes and a pilot episode, ending in 1990. Fox abruptly cancelled the series after the season. Beginning in 1994, the network continued the story in five TV movies, which brought back the entire cast. The installments include Dark Horizon (1994), Body and Soul (1995), Millennium (1996), The Enemy Within (1996), and The Udara Legacy (1997).

Novels ðŸ”—

Pocket Books, a division of Simon & Schuster, published a novel series connected to the franchise starting in 1993. Judith and Garfield Reeves-Stevens, known for their work in Star Trek, wrote a novel entitled Day of Descent. Some novels served as prequels to the movie sequels, such as K.W. Jeter’s Cross of Blood, a tie-in to the Dark Horizon film, and Peter David’s Body and Soul, which became one of the sequels of the same name. The novels regularly addressed racism and discrimination with extraterrestrial themes. K. W. Jeter and Barry B. Longyear were regular contributors to the series with novels like, The Change and Slag Like Me.

Comics ðŸ”—

From 1990 to 1992, Malibu Comics published several comics adapting the Alien Nation storyline. Among the first released titles were The Spartans, created with the help of author Bill Spangler and illustrator James Tucker, and A Breed Apart, authored by Steve Jones. Other titles included Public Enemy, authored by Sandy Carruthers and illustrated by Lowell Cunningham, and a crossover series with the Planet of the Apes franchise titled Ape Nation. The Ape Nation series included four different adventures called Plans, Pasts, Pawns and Pains along with a collector’s edition. Other contributors to the series included illustrators Terry Pallott and Leonard Kirk to titles like, The Skin Trade.

Remake ðŸ”—

On March 25, 2015, Fox announced a remake with Art Marcum and Matt Holloway writing. On September 9, 2016, Deadline reported that Jeff Nichols would write and direct the film. On January 25, 2021, it was announced that Jeff Nichols would remake the film as a ten-part television series. On June 21, 2024, it was reported Nichols was developing an original sci-fi feature film for Paramount instead of an Alien Nation project.

Alien Apocalypse (2005 film) ðŸ”—

This entry describes the 2005 American science fiction TV film Alien Apocalypse.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section presents the film’s promotional poster and basic information in a table format. Key details include:

  • Writer and Director: Josh Becker
  • Starring: Bruce Campbell, Renee O’Connor, Remington Franklin, Michael Cory Davis, and Peter Jason
  • Theme Music Composer: Joseph LoDuca

  • Production: Jeff Franklin and Bob Perkis
  • Cinematography: David Worth
  • Editor: Shawn Paper
  • Production Company: Syfy
  • Original Release: March 26, 2005
  • Network: Sci Fi Channel

It establishes the film as a Sci Fi Channel original movie.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot summary details the events of the film:

  • Astronaut Dr. Ivan Hood (Bruce Campbell) and his companion Kelly return to Earth after a 40-year space mission.
  • They discover Earth has been conquered by giant termite-like aliens who used EMP bombs to disable the planet 20 years prior.
  • Humans are enslaved and forced to work in camps.
  • Dr. Hood and Kelly are captured near the ruins of Portland, Oregon.
  • They plan an escape after learning of a surviving President.
  • Kelly is recaptured, and Dr. Hood seeks out the President, eventually finding him a broken man.
  • Dr. Hood rallies escaped slaves to attack the alien camp and rescue Kelly.
  • The attack is successful with the help of the President’s forces.
  • Dr. Hood becomes known as “The Great Exterminator” and continues to fight the aliens.

It includes an image of Josh Becker directing the film.

item.title: E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (1982 film)
item.description:
E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (1982 film) ðŸ”—

A comprehensive overview of the 1982 American science fiction film produced and directed by Steven Spielberg and written by Melissa Mathison. The film tells the story of a boy, Elliott, who befriends an extraterrestrial stranded on Earth.

Plot ðŸ”—

A race of alien botanists visits Earth, but one of them gets separated from the group and is left behind. The alien takes shelter in a shed belonging to the family of ten-year-old Elliott Taylor. Elliott lures the alien back to his home with Reese’s Pieces, and he hides the creature in his room. Elliott introduces E.T. to his older brother, Michael, and five-year-old sister Gertie, who agree to keep E.T. hidden from their mother, Mary. Elliott and the creature begin to bond, they start to share thoughts and emotions. E.T. displays telekinetic abilities and revives a dead chrysanthemum.

At school, Elliott becomes intoxicated because E.T. is drinking beer and watching television at home. Inspired by a Buck Rogers comic strip, E.T. builds a makeshift device to “phone home”, using various parts around the Taylor home. On Halloween, the children disguise E.T. as a ghost and Elliott sneaks E.T. into the forest, where they set up the device to call E.T.’s people. Elliott begs E.T. to stay on Earth with him, before falling asleep and waking alone in the forest the next day. He returns home to his worried family, while Michael searches for E.T., finding him pale and weakened in a culvert. He takes E.T. home, where Elliott is also growing weaker, and reveal the creature to Mary just before government agents invade and quarantine the house. The lead agent, Keys, asks for Elliott’s help to save E.T., stating that meeting aliens was his childhood dream and he considers E.T’s arrival a genuine miracle. However, E.T. dies while Elliott rapidly recovers. Left alone to say goodbye, Elliott tells E.T. that he loves him, but E.T.’s heart begins to glow and he is revived and restored to health. E.T. tells Elliott that his people are returning for him.

Elliott and Michael flee with E.T. on their bikes, flanked by Michael’s friends who help them evade the pursuing authorities. Heading towards a roadblock, E.T. levitates the boys to safety and lands them in the forest. E.T.’s ship arrives, and he says goodbye to Michael and Gertie, who gifts him the chrysanthemum he previously revived. Elliott tearfully asks E.T. to stay, but E.T. places his glowing finger on Elliott’s head and tells him that he will always be there. The children, Mary, and Keys observe as the ship blasts off into space, leaving a rainbow in the sky.

Cast ðŸ”—

The main cast includes:

  • Dee Wallace as Mary Taylor, the single mother.
  • Henry Thomas as Elliott Taylor, the boy who befriends E.T.
  • Peter Coyote as Keys, the government agent.
  • Robert MacNaughton as Michael Taylor, Elliott’s older brother.
  • Drew Barrymore as Gertie Taylor, Elliott’s younger sister.

Other cast members include K.C. Martel, Sean Frye, C. Thomas Howell, Erika Eleniak, David O’Dell, Richard Swingler, Frank Toth, Robert Barton, Michael Darrell, and Pat Welsh as the voice of E.T.

Production ðŸ”—

Details the development, pre-production, casting, filming, and music of the movie.

Development ðŸ”—

The film’s concept originated from an imaginary friend Steven Spielberg created after his parents’ divorce. He initially planned a darker project called Night Skies but developed a subplot into what became E.T. Melissa Mathison wrote the first draft, titled E.T. and Me.

Pre-production ðŸ”—

Carlo Rambaldi designed the animatronics for E.T., inspired by his painting Women of Delta and the faces of Carl Sandburg, Albert Einstein, and Ernest Hemingway. Kathleen Kennedy visited the Jules Stein Eye Institute to study eyes for E.T. Four heads were created for filming, one as the main animatronic and the others for facial expressions, as well as a costume. Tamara De Treaux, Pat Bilon, and Matthew DeMeritt took turns wearing the costume. Mars, Incorporated refused to allow M&M’s to be used in the film, so The Hershey Company was asked if Reese’s Pieces could be used, and it agreed. Henry Feinberg created E.T.’s communicator device.

Casting ðŸ”—

Spielberg cast Henry Thomas as Elliott after an impressive improvised audition scene. Robert MacNaughton played Michael, and Drew Barrymore was cast as Gertie. Pat Welsh provided the major voice work for E.T., with additional sounds from Debra Winger, Spielberg, and various animals. A scene featuring Harrison Ford as the school principal was cut.

Filming ðŸ”—

Principal photography began on September 8, 1981, in Los Angeles County and the San Fernando Valley, under the cover name A Boy’s Life. Filming locations included Culver City High School, Northridge, Tujunga, Laird International Studios in Culver City, and a redwood forest near Crescent City in Northern California. The exterior Halloween scene and the “flying bicycle” chase scenes were filmed in Porter Ranch. The film was shot in roughly chronological order to achieve convincing emotional performances from the young cast. Sean Frye revealed how the visual effect close-up shots for the climax of the “flying bicycle” chase scene were filmed. BMX riders Robert Cardoza, Greg Maes, and David Lee served as stunt doubles for the scene.

Music ðŸ”—

John Williams composed the score, taking a modernist approach with polytonality and the Lydian mode. Spielberg edited the final chase sequence to suit Williams’ music.

Themes ðŸ”—

The film explores themes of divorce, alienation, growing up, and communication. Critics have noted parallels between E.T. and Elliott, as well as religious parallels between E.T. and Jesus. Some see the movie as a modern fairy tale, drawing comparisons to Peter Pan and The Wizard of Oz. Kathleen Kennedy highlighted tolerance as an important theme.

Reception ðŸ”—

Details the film’s release, sales, critical response, and accolades.

Release and sales ðŸ”—

E.T. premiered at the 1982 Cannes Film Festival and was released in the United States on June 11, 1982. It opened at number one at the US box office and stayed at the top for six weeks. In 1983, E.T. surpassed Star Wars to become the highest-grossing film of all time. The film was also a merchandising success, with dolls selling 15 million units by September 1982 and becoming the best-selling toy that Christmas season. The film was re-released in 1985 and 2002, earning another $60 million and $68 million respectively. It was re-released in IMAX on August 12, 2022, to commemorate the film’s 40th anniversary.

Home media ðŸ”—

E.T. was released on VHS and LaserDisc on October 27, 1988. The videos were priced with a recommended retail price of $24.95, the lowest initial price at the time for a major movie compared to the normal price of $89.95. The film doubled the record pre-orders of Cinderella released the same month and went on to sell over 15 million VHS units in the United States, and grossed over $250 million in video sales revenue.

Critical response ðŸ”—

The film received near-universal acclaim. Roger Ebert gave it four out of four stars, and Michael Sragow of Rolling Stone called Spielberg “a space age Jean Renoir.” George Will was one of few to pan the film. The film holds a 99% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes.

Accolades ðŸ”—

The film was nominated for nine Oscars at the 55th Academy Awards, winning four: Best Original Score, Best Sound, Best Sound Effects Editing, and Best Visual Effects. It also won Golden Globe Awards for Best Picture (Drama) and Best Original Score.

Legacy ðŸ”—

The film has been voted one of the greatest films of all time by the American Film Institute. The line “E.T. phone home” was ranked 15th on AFI’s 100 Years…100 Movie Quotes list. In 1994, it was selected for preservation in the U.S. National Film Registry. In 2023, actress Rita Moreno named E.T. as one of her top five favorite films. Many people in the world of entertainment have cited E.T. as among their favorite films, including filmmakers Stanley Kubrick, Sidney Lumet, Edgar Wright, J. A. Bayona, Dustin Lance Black, Spenser Cohen, Dustin Guy Defa, Gareth Edwards, Michael Giacchino, Sarah Greenwood, Chad Hartigan, Max Hechtman, Jordan Horowitz, Phil Joanou, Travis Knight, David Lowery, Rod Roddenberry, CÃ©line Sciamma, Ed Solomon, Goran Stolevski, Clement Virgo and Molly Manning Walker, actors

item.title: Contact (1997 film)
item.description:
Contact (1997 film) ðŸ”—

Contact is a 1997 American science fiction drama film directed by Robert Zemeckis, based on Carl Sagan’s 1985 novel of the same name. The film stars Jodie Foster as Dr. Eleanor Arroway, a SETI scientist who discovers evidence of extraterrestrial life and is chosen to make first contact.

Plot ðŸ”—

Dr. Ellie Arroway, driven by the childhood loss of her father and inspired by his encouragement of her amateur radio hobby, dedicates her life to SETI research at the Arecibo Observatory. Facing funding cuts led by President’s science advisor David Drumlin, she secures private funding from the reclusive billionaire S.R. Hadden to continue her work at the Very Large Array (VLA) in New Mexico.

Four years later, Arroway discovers a signal from the star Vega containing a sequence of prime numbers. The discovery leads to a global effort to decode the message, which is complicated by Drumlin and the National Security Council’s attempts to control the facility. The signal is found to contain a video of Adolf Hitler’s opening address at the 1936 Summer Olympics, the first Earth transmission strong enough to reach Vega.

Arroway’s team decodes the signal, revealing schematics for a complex machine designed to transport a single person. Multiple nations collaborate to fund the machine’s construction at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral. An international panel is formed to select a candidate for the journey. Arroway is a leading contender, but her atheism, highlighted by panel member Palmer Joss, jeopardizes her selection. Drumlin is chosen, but a religious terrorist destroys the machine during testing, killing Drumlin and others.

Hadden, now terminally ill and living on the Mir space station, informs Arroway of a second, secretly constructed machine in Hokkaido, Japan. Arroway is selected to use it. Equipped with recording devices, she enters the pod and travels through wormholes, observing alien structures and a celestial event. She finds herself on a beach resembling a childhood drawing of Pensacola, Florida, and encounters an alien taking the form of her deceased father, who explains that the aliens have been monitoring humanity’s radio emissions and have deemed them ready for first contact.

Arroway awakens in the pod, which has only fallen a short distance into a safety net. Mission control insists that the experiment achieved nothing, and her recording devices show only static. A Congressional Committee, led by Michael Kitz, investigates the possibility of a hoax orchestrated by Hadden, who has since died. Arroway asks the committee to accept her testimony on faith, emphasizing the profound impact of her experience. Kitz and Rachel Constantine, a White House official, acknowledge that Arroway’s device recorded 18 hours of static. Arroway receives continued funding for SETI research at the VLA.

Cast ðŸ”—

The film features a cast of notable actors:

  • Jodie Foster as Dr. Eleanor “Ellie” Ann Arroway
  • Jena Malone as young Ellie
  • Matthew McConaughey as Palmer Joss
  • David Morse as Theodore Arroway
  • Tom Skerritt as Dr. David Drumlin
  • James Woods as Michael Kitz
  • John Hurt as S. R. Hadden
  • William Fichtner as Kent Clarke
  • Angela Bassett as Rachel Constantine
  • Jake Busey as Joseph
  • Rob Lowe as Richard Rank
  • Geoffrey Blake as Fisher
  • Max Martini as Willie
  • Steven Ford as Major John Russell
  • Jay Leno as himself
  • Larry King as himself
  • Ann Druyan as herself

Production ðŸ”—

Development ðŸ”—

Carl Sagan conceived Contact in 1979 with Lynda Obst and Peter Guber at Casablanca FilmWorks. Sagan and Ann Druyan completed the film treatment in 1980, aiming to depict a realistic first contact scenario. Kip Thorne consulted on wormhole travel. The character of Ellie Arroway was not directly inspired by Jill Tarter, though Foster met her for research. The name Ellie was inspired by Eleanor Roosevelt.

The project faced numerous rewrites and stalled development. Sagan rewrote Contact as a novel, published in 1985. Roland JoffÃ© and George Miller were initially attached to direct but later departed.

Filming ðŸ”—

Robert Zemeckis took over as director, securing artistic control. Filming began in September 1996 and concluded in February 1997. Key locations included the Very Large Array (VLA) in New Mexico, Warner Hollywood Studios, and Culver Studios. CNN news personalities were scripted into the film to enhance realism. Second unit filming took place at the Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico, Fiji, Saint John, US Virgin Islands, and Newfoundland, Canada. Technical consultants from the SETI Institute, Caltech, and a former White House staff member were involved. Sagan participated in the production until his death in December 1996, and the film is dedicated to him.

Visual effects ðŸ”—

Eight VFX companies, including Sony Pictures Imageworks, Weta Digital, and Industrial Light & Magic, collaborated on the visual effects. Weta Digital designed the wormhole sequence. Digital alterations were made to news footage of Bill Clinton. Digital color correction addressed continuity issues during location shooting. The opening scene is a five-minute CGI sequence depicting a zoom out from Earth to the distant universe. The mirror shot was created through three different plates and manipulated in CGI. The machine was designed by concept artist Steve Burg, reusing a design he created as a “time-displacement device” for an unused scene in Terminator 2.

Music ðŸ”—

Alan Silvestri composed and conducted the original score. A soundtrack album was released in August 1997.

Themes ðŸ”—

Contact explores the cultural conflicts between religion and science, particularly concerning the existence of God. The film presents various viewpoints on faith and scientific evidence. It depicts intense public debate about the implications of alien contact, including questions about morality and the role of science. The film raises questions about the authenticity of Arroway’s journey, leaving room for doubt. The film suggests that science and religion can coexist.

Release ðŸ”—

Contact’s release in July 1997 boosted interest in Sagan’s novel. The book appeared on The New York Times Best Seller list. The film premiered on July 1, 1997, and was released in the United States and Canada on July 11, 1997.

Critical reception ðŸ”—

The film received generally positive reviews. Critics praised its exploration of scientific and theological concepts but noted weaknesses in storytelling.

Awards ðŸ”—

Contact won the Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation and two Saturn Awards. It received nominations for an Academy Award for Best Sound and a Golden Globe Award for Best Lead Actress in a Motion Picture â€“ Drama (Jodie Foster).

Reactions ðŸ”—

Bill Clinton ðŸ”—

The film used digitally altered footage of President Bill Clinton, leading to a protest from the White House.

CNN ðŸ”—

CNN chairman Tom Johnson expressed regret over allowing CNN staff to appear in the film, citing concerns about blurring the lines between news and entertainment.

NASA ðŸ”—

The scene involving a cyanide pill caused controversy, with conflicting accounts from NASA advisor Gerald D. Griffin and Carl Sagan.

SETI ðŸ”—

SETI.org published a review of the film, highlighting its accuracy in depicting SETI research.

Lawsuits ðŸ”—

Director George Miller unsuccessfully sued Warner Bros. over breach of contract policies. Francis Ford Coppola sued Warner Bros. and Sagan, claiming that Sagan’s novel was based on a story they had developed together. Coppola’s claim was dismissed.

item.title: Alienoid (2022 film)
item.description:
Alienoid (2022 film) ðŸ”—

A 2022 South Korean science fiction action film directed by Choi Dong-hoon, starring Ryu Jun-yeol, Kim Woo-bin, and Kim Tae-ri. The film involves time travel between the Goryeo era and the present day, with the appearance of aliens. It was released in IMAX and 4DX formats. A sequel, Alienoid: Return to the Future, was released in 2024.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot alternates between the modern day and the Goryeo era.

Prologue: 1380 A.D. ðŸ”—

Monk warriors fail to defeat an alien and its human host. Guard and Thunder, humanoid robots from the future, extract the alien. The dying host asks Guard to care for her baby, but Guard initially refuses due to non-interference policies. Thunder smuggles the infant back with them to the modern day.

Timeline 1: 2012-2022 A.D. ðŸ”—

Guard raises the baby girl, Yi-an, without revealing his true identity. Yi-an becomes suspicious and discovers the truth about Guard, Thunder, and her origins.

Yi-an finds her way to Jisan Hospital, the site of an incoming alien prisoner transport. Guard and Thunder explain alien imprisonment mechanics. A prisoner-aligned alien ship arrives, planning to awaken the Controller and release haava to transform Earth’s atmosphere, awakening all alien prisoners and poisoning humanity. The pilot awakens the Controller and releases haava, devastating the city and awakening other prisoners.

Guard, Thunder, and Yi-an kill the alien pilot and prevent further haava release. Badly wounded, Yi-an travels back in time with the aliens, intending to strand them in the past. Guard is destroyed, Thunder sinks in a river, and the Controller is forced to abandon its host.

Timeline 2: 1391 A.D. ðŸ”—

Ten years after Thunder crash-lands, a Taoist bounty hunter named Mureuk pursues the Divine Blade (Guard’s power source). Mureuk meets martial arts figures like the Monk Guru, the Dual Mages, and Dogturd. He also meets Yi-an (the “Girl Who Shoots Thunder”) and Suiter and Ja-jang, aliens from the future who have taken over a local cult. The Divine Blade and Thunder’s location are key to controlling the haava release.

A chaotic battle ensues. Yi-an lures one alien away, while the other is defeated. Yi-an approaches Thunder’s location.

Monk Guru, the Dual Mages, and Dogturd were all near the initial alien crash and are potential hosts for the Controller. However, Mureuk, Monk Guru’s apprentice, rescued Yi-an and became the Controller’s new host, losing his memories.

Filming took place over 13 months, with both parts filmed simultaneously. Choi Dong-hoon spent two and a half years writing the script. Ryu Seong-hee and Lee Ha-jun were the art directors. Dexter Studio handled the CG. Filming locations included Andong, North Gyeongsang Province. The production cost for both parts was estimated at 40 billion won.

item.title: Alien vs. Predator (2004 film)
item.description:
Alien vs. Predator (2004 film) ðŸ”—

A 2004 science fiction action horror film directed by Paul W. S. Anderson, Alien vs. Predator brings together the titular creatures from the Alien and Predator franchises. The story draws inspiration from a 1989 comic book and incorporates elements of Aztec mythology and the writings of Erich von DÃ¤niken.

Plot ðŸ”—

In Antarctica, a Predator ship melts a hole in the ice, revealing a buried pyramid. Charles Weyland assembles a team to investigate. The team discovers evidence of an ancient civilization and a sacrificial chamber. Three Predators arrive and descend into the pyramid, where they encounter the humans and awakened Xenomorphs. Battles ensue, and Lex Woods and Sebastian De Rosa learn about the Predators’ history on Earth through hieroglyphs. They discover that the Predators have been visiting Earth for millennia, teaching humans to build pyramids and using them for rite of passage rituals involving Xenomorphs. Lex and Sebastian ally with a Predator named Scar to prevent the Xenomorphs from escaping. Scar destroys the pyramid, but the Xenomorph Queen attacks. Lex and Scar defeat the Queen, and an elder Predator gifts Lex a spear. A Predalien chestburster erupts from Scar’s body on the Predator spaceship.

Cast ðŸ”—

Sanaa Lathan stars as Alexa “Lex” Woods, an experienced guide. Raoul Bova plays Professor Sebastian De Rosa, an Italian archaeologist. Lance Henriksen portrays Charles Bishop Weyland, the head of Weyland Corporation. Ewen Bremner is Dr. Graeme Miller, the main scientist. Colin Salmon plays Maxwell Stafford, Weyland’s assistant. Tommy Flanagan is Mark Verheiden, a member of the armed escort. Tom Woodruff Jr. plays the Alien/Grid, and Ian Whyte plays the Predator/Scar and other Predators.

Production ðŸ”—

Fifth Alien film and sequel ðŸ”—

James Cameron had been working on a fifth Alien film, and Ridley Scott had a concept to explore the origins of the alien creatures. However, upon learning of Alien vs. Predator, Cameron ceased work, believing it would damage the franchise. Ridley Scott also expressed disinterest in the Alien vs. Predator films.

Development ðŸ”—

The concept originated from the Aliens versus Predator comic book. Screenwriter Peter Briggs created a spec screenplay in 1990â€“1991. The project was delayed due to Alien Resurrection. Paul W. S. Anderson pitched John Davis a story adapting the Machiko Noguchi series. Anderson began working on the film after completing the script for Resident Evil: Apocalypse, with Shane Salerno co-writing.

Story and setting ðŸ”—

Influenced by Erich von DÃ¤niken and Aztec mythology, Anderson depicted Predators teaching humans to build pyramids and being treated as gods. The Predators would use Earth for rite of passage rituals every 100 years, hunting Aliens. If overwhelmed, the Predators would use self-destruct weapons. H. P. Lovecraft’s At the Mountains of Madness and the Aliens vs. Predator comic series influenced the story. The film is set on Bouvet Island in Antarctica.

Casting ðŸ”—

Lance Henriksen was the first actor cast, maintaining continuity with the Alien series. He plays Charles Bishop Weyland, tying into the Weyland-Yutani Corporation. Sanaa Lathan was cast as Alexa Woods. Arnold Schwarzenegger was considered for a cameo as Major Alan “Dutch” Schaeffer from Predator. Sigourney Weaver declined to participate.

Filming and set designs ðŸ”—

Production began in 2003 at Barrandov Studios in Prague. Richard Bridgland designed sets, props, and vehicles. 25 to 30 life-sized sets were constructed, including interiors of the pyramid. The pyramid’s designs were influenced by Egyptian, Cambodian, and Aztec civilizations. Miniatures were used to enhance realism.

Visual effects and creatures ðŸ”—

Amalgamated Dynamics, Inc. (ADI) designed costumes, miniatures, and effects. The Predators’ wrist blades were extended, and a larger mechanical plasma caster was created. Each Predator was given a unique mask. A hydraulic Alien puppet was created for faster movements. CGI use was minimized. The Alien queen was filmed using practical, puppet, and computer-generated versions.

Music ðŸ”—

Harald Kloser composed the film’s score, recorded in London. The score album was released on iTunes and CD, receiving mixed reviews.

Release ðŸ”—

Home media ðŸ”—

Alien vs. Predator was released on VHS, DVD, and PSP UMD Movies. The DVD included audio commentaries, a “Making of” featurette, and deleted scenes. An “Extreme Edition” and an “Unrated Edition” were also released.

Reception ðŸ”—

Box office ðŸ”—

Alien vs. Predator grossed $177.4 million worldwide.

Critical response ðŸ”—

The film received generally negative reviews. Rotten Tomatoes reported 21% positive reviews, with the consensus being “Gore without scares and cardboard cut-out characters make this clash of the monsters a dull sit.” Metacritic gave the film a score of 29 out of 100, indicating “generally unfavorable” reviews.

Other media ðŸ”—

Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem was released in December 2007.

The Predator (2018) featured Lex Wood’s Xenomorph-bone spear.

Several video games were released, including Alien vs. Predator (mobile) and Aliens vs. Pinball.

item.title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind
item.description:
Close Encounters of the Third Kind ðŸ”—

A 1977 American science fiction drama film directed and written by Steven Spielberg. It tells the story of Roy Neary, an everyday blue-collar worker in Indiana, and Jillian, a single mother, whose lives are changed after encounters with unidentified flying objects.

Plot ðŸ”—

In 1977, French scientist Claude Lacombe and his team examine Flight 19, found abandoned in the Sonoran Desert, and the SS Cotopaxi, found in the Gobi Desert. Near Indianapolis, Roy Neary has a close encounter with a UFO, becoming obsessed with a mountain shape. Jillian Guiler’s son, Barry, is abducted by a UFO. Lacombe’s team investigates increasing UFO activity, discovering a five-tone musical phrase. The coordinates point to Devils Tower in Wyoming. Roy and Jillian, along with others experiencing visions, head to Devils Tower, which is being evacuated by the US Army. They reach the site as UFOs appear. Scientists communicate with the UFOs using light and sound. A mothership arrives, releasing humans and animals, including Barry. Roy is chosen to join the extraterrestrials, entering the mothership as it departs.

Cast ðŸ”—

Richard Dreyfuss stars as Roy Neary, an electrical lineman. FranÃ§ois Truffaut plays Claude Lacombe, a French scientist. Teri Garr is Ronnie Neary, Roy’s wife, and Melinda Dillon portrays Jillian Guiler. Cary Guffey plays Barry Guiler, Jillian’s son. Bob Balaban appears as David Laughlin, Lacombe’s assistant.

Production ðŸ”—

Development ðŸ”—

The film’s inspiration came from Steven Spielberg’s childhood experience watching a meteor shower. He developed a deal with Columbia Pictures in 1973. J. Allen Hynek, a UFO consultant, was hired. NASA declined to cooperate.

Filming ðŸ”—

Principal photography began in May 1976. Filming locations included Burbank, California; Devils Tower National Monument in Wyoming; airship hangars in Mobile, Alabama; and a railroad depot in Bay Minette, Alabama. The Sonora Desert sequence was filmed at the Dumont Dunes, California, and the Dharmsala-India exteriors were filmed near Mumbai, India. Technical and budgetary problems arose during filming.

Visual effects ðŸ”—

Douglas Trumbull served as the visual effects supervisor, and Carlo Rambaldi designed the extraterrestrials. The mothership was designed by Ralph McQuarrie and built by Greg Jein. The look of the ship was inspired by an oil refinery Spielberg saw at night in India.

Post-production ðŸ”—

Michael Kahn was the film editor. Pick-ups were commissioned, with John A. Alonzo, LÃ¡szlÃ³ KovÃ¡cs, and Douglas Slocombe working on them.

Music ðŸ”—

John Williams composed the film score, including the iconic five-tone motif. Spielberg called Williams’s work “When You Wish Upon a Star meets science fiction.” Phillip Dodds from ARP Instruments installed the synthesizer on set and was cast as Jean Claude.

Themes ðŸ”—

The film explores themes of humanity’s readiness to join the cosmos, the impact of new technologies, and spiritual yearning. Judeo-Christian analogies are present, with Devils Tower paralleling Mount Sinai. Communication and tolerance are also highlighted.

Release and reception ðŸ”—

Box office ðŸ”—

The film premiered in New York City on November 16, 1977, and was released nationally in December. It became a box office success, grossing over $300 million worldwide.

Critical reception ðŸ”—

Reviews were mostly positive, with praise for Spielberg’s vision and the film’s climax. Some critics noted a lack of warmth compared to Star Wars.

Reissues and home media ðŸ”—

Several versions of the film have been released, including the original theatrical version, the Special Edition (1980), and the Director’s Cut (1998). The Special Edition added scenes, including the interior of the mothership, while the Director’s Cut removed the mothership interior.

Accolades ðŸ”—

The film received numerous awards and nominations, including Academy Awards, British Academy Film Awards, and Golden Globe Awards. It was selected for preservation in the National Film Registry in 2007.

Legacy ðŸ”—

Close Encounters is credited with launching the reemergence of science fiction films in the 1980s. Spielberg donated to the Planetary Society for extraterrestrial research.

Alien ðŸ”—

The Alien franchise is a science fiction horror and action media franchise that began with the 1979 film Alien. The series centers on Ellen Ripley’s battles with the extraterrestrial Xenomorph and the prequel series following the android David 8 and the Engineers. The franchise is owned by 20th Century Studios.

Created by: Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett Original Work: Alien (1979) Owner: 20th Century Studios Years Active: 1979â€“present

Premise ðŸ”—

The franchise depicts deadly encounters between humanity and the Xenomorph, a hostile extraterrestrial species. Humanity is a space-faring species, and space journeys require cryosleep. The megacorporation Weyland-Yutani Corp seeks to profit from the Aliens, manipulating and endangering characters. The series also explores the origin of the human race, with the Engineers sacrificing themselves to spark the genesis of mankind.

Background ðŸ”—

Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett collaborated on the script for Alien. Brandywine Productions bought the script, and 20th Century Fox invested millions after the success of Star Wars. The Ripley character was initially to be played by Tom Skerritt, but Sigourney Weaver was cast instead. Ridley Scott directed the film. H. R. Giger designed the alien creature and derelict ship, MÅ“bius created the spacesuits, and Ron Cobb provided the industrial design for the sets.

James Cameron expressed interest in continuing the Alien story in 1983. After Cameron’s The Terminator became a hit, he and Gale Anne Hurd were approved to direct and produce Aliens. Following the second film, Weaver was not interested in returning, but she was offered a $5 million salary and a producer credit to make Alien 3. Alien 3 faced script difficulties, trouble securing a director, and studio interference.

Production on Alien Resurrection began in 1996. Weaver joined the project after being offered an $11 million salary and more creative control. The script resurrected the Ripley character via human cloning. Joss Whedon later said that he thought it had done “everything wrong” with his script.

item.title: Contact (1985 novel)
item.description:
Contact (1985 novel) ðŸ”—

This article provides information about Carl Sagan’s 1985 science fiction novel, Contact. It distinguishes the novel from other works with the same title.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot centers around Eleanor “Ellie” Arroway, a scientist with a strong aptitude for science and mathematics. Her father’s death deeply affects her, and she finds herself at odds with her stepfather. Ellie pursues a career in radio astronomy, eventually directing Project Argus, a SETI initiative in New Mexico.

The project detects a signal from Vega, which is analyzed and found to contain a retransmission of Hitler’s 1936 Olympic speech. Later, a third message reveals plans for an advanced machine. Ellie works with Ken der Heer and Vaygay Lunacharsky to decipher the message. Religious leaders Billy Jo Rankin and Palmer Joss also become involved. The final piece of the message is discovered with the help of S.R. Hadden, revealing the primer needed to build the machine.

A race to build the machine ensues between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. An extremist bombing delays the project. Ellie learns Hadden has secretly built a third machine in Hokkaido, Japan. Ellie, Vaygay, Devi Sukhavati, Abonnema Eda, and Xi Qiaomu travel through wormholes to a station near the Milky Way’s center. There, they meet extraterrestrials who explain their motives and a project to alter the universe’s properties.

Upon returning to Earth, the travelers find their journey seemingly took no time at all. Their video recordings are erased, and officials suspect a hoax. Ellie finds evidence of her journey in the digits of pi, confirming the reality of her experience.

Publication history ðŸ”—

As a child, Sagan was inspired by science fiction and fantasy. He preferred realistic stories that helped readers understand real science and history. In 1978, Sagan predicted that science fiction would make young people interested in extraterrestrial contact. Simon & Schuster gave Sagan a $2 million advance on the novel in 1981. Kip Thorne provided Sagan with ideas on wormholes. Eleanor Arroway was named after Eleanor Roosevelt and Voltaire. The character is based on Jill Tarter. The novel won the Locus Award for Best First Novel in 1986.

item.title: Alien invasion
item.description:
Alien Invasion ðŸ”—

Alien invasion, also known as space invasion, is a prevalent theme in science fiction stories and films. It involves extraterrestrial lifeforms invading Earth with various motives, such as exterminating or enslaving humanity, harvesting humans for food, stealing resources, or destroying the planet. This theme is a subgenre of invasion literature, popularized by H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds, and is a type of first contact science fiction. Experts consider an actual alien invasion unlikely due to the immense costs involved.

Origins ðŸ”—

This section discusses the origins of the alien invasion theme in fiction. H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds (1898) is considered the seminal alien invasion story, establishing themes like first contact and interplanetary war. However, earlier stories exist, such as Robert Potter’s The Germ Growers (1892), which features a covert alien invasion. The section also mentions Wells’ proposed guerrilla war scenario in The War of the Worlds. Garrett P. Serviss’ Edison’s Conquest of Mars, an unauthorized sequel to The War of the Worlds, depicts Thomas Edison leading a counterattack on Mars. The reprinting of The War of the Worlds in the United States in 1927 coincided with the Golden Age of Science Fiction. John W. Campbell and other science fiction writers, including Isaac Asimov, Arthur C. Clarke, Clifford D. Simak, and Robert A. Heinlein, further developed the theme.

Variations ðŸ”—

This section explores different variations of the alien invasion theme.

Alien Infiltration ðŸ”—

This variation involves invaders taking human form and infiltrating society, even taking control of command positions. Their goal may be to take over the world or prepare for a full-scale invasion. This theme reflects Cold War fears of communist infiltration. The Reptilian conspiracy theory is mentioned as a real-world belief in covert alien infiltration.

Beneficial Alien Invasion ðŸ”—

This variation presents aliens colonizing Earth to “civilize” humanity or secretly aiding humans to prevent self-destruction. Henry Slesar’s The Delegate from Venus is mentioned. Examples include Klaatu and Gort in The Day the Earth Stood Still, Gene Roddenberry’s The Questor Tapes and Star Trek episode “Assignment: Earth”, Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End, Crest of the Stars, the film Arrival, and David Brin’s Uplift Universe series.

Invasion by Humans ðŸ”—

This variation reverses the roles, with humans invading or attacking extraterrestrial lifeforms. Examples include the short story Sentry, the video game Phantasy Star II, The Martian Chronicles by Ray Bradbury, the Imperium of Man in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, Invaders from Earth by Robert Silverberg, Ender’s Game by Orson Scott Card, and the movies Battle for Terra, Planet 51, and Avatar.

Feasibility ðŸ”—

This section discusses the feasibility of an actual alien invasion. Seth Shostak of the SETI Institute believes it’s unlikely due to resource availability and the likelihood of initial contact being through robots. David Morrison of NASA-Ames Research Center suggests first contact would be via radio communication.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related topics, including interplanetary contamination, potential cultural impact of extraterrestrial contact, space colonization, UFO religion, The Kraken Wakes, list of films featuring space stations, and the Wow! signal.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the references used in the article, providing sources for the information presented.

Extra Terrestrial Visitors ðŸ”—

This entry details the 1983 French-Spanish science fiction film Extra Terrestrial Visitors (also known as Los nuevos extraterrestres and Pod People). It covers the film’s production, plot, cast, release, and reception, including its later cult status due to being featured on Mystery Science Theater 3000.

Plot ðŸ”—

The story unfolds in the woods of New England, where egg poachers stumble upon a cave containing alien eggs. After one poacher destroys the eggs, a vengeful alien begins targeting the poachers and a rock band camping nearby. Meanwhile, a young boy named Tommy discovers the remaining egg, which hatches into a creature he names Trumpy. Tommy and Trumpy become friends, and Trumpy develops telekinetic powers. The alien mother searches for her offspring, leading to encounters with the rock band and Tommy’s family. The film culminates in a confrontation between the humans and the alien mother, with tragic consequences for some characters. Tommy and Trumpy say goodbye before Tommy returns to his family.

Cast ðŸ”—

The cast includes Ian Serra as Rick, Nina Ferrer as Sharon, Susana Bequer as Lara Stapleton, Sara Palmer as Kathy, Ã“scar MartÃ­n as Tommy Stevens, Maria Albert as Tracy, Emilio Linder as Brian, Concha Cuetos as Molly Stevens, Manuel Pereiro as Bill Stevens, and Frank BraÃ±a as Burt.

Production ðŸ”—

Extra Terrestrial Visitors was a co-production between France and Spain, filmed in Madrid. The cast consisted largely of Spanish actors, and the film was shot in both Spanish and French, later dubbed in post-production. Juan Piquer SimÃ³n directed the film. Faruk Alatan, Dick Randall, and Edward L. Montoro produced the film.

Release ðŸ”—

The film was initially released in France. In the United States, it was sometimes shown on television under the title The Unearthling. Film Ventures International later acquired the film and re-titled it Pod People for U.S. television distribution.

Reception and legacy ðŸ”—

The film received negative reviews, with some finding it unintentionally funny. Its legacy is largely tied to its appearance on Mystery Science Theater 3000 (MST3K), which lampooned the Pod People version of the film.

Mystery Science Theater 3000 ðŸ”—

The film gained popularity after being featured on Mystery Science Theater 3000 in 1991. The MST3K episode used a print of the film re-titled Pod People by Film Ventures International. The opening and ending credits of Pod People are superimposed over footage from The Galaxy Invader. The fictional pop band’s song “Hear the Engines Roll” became a recurring joke on the show.

Home media ðŸ”—

The film has been released on VHS under various titles, including The Unearthling and E. T.: The Second Coming. The MST3K version of the film has been released on DVD and Blu-ray.

item.title: The Alien
item.description:
The Alien ðŸ”—

This article details the history of The Alien, an unproduced science fiction film conceived by Indian filmmaker Satyajit Ray in the late 1960s. The film was a joint venture between India and the United States, with Columbia Pictures slated to produce it. Despite the involvement of notable actors like Peter Sellers and Marlon Brando, the film was ultimately shelved.

Plot ðŸ”—

The story centers around an alien spaceship that lands in a rural village in Bengal, India. The villagers, awestruck by the craft, begin to worship it. The alien, named “Mr. Ang,” communicates with a young boy named Haba through dreams and engages in playful pranks within the village. The narrative also includes an Indian businessman, a journalist from Calcutta (now Kolkata), and an American engineer. A specific scene is highlighted, describing the alien’s interaction with plant life, showcasing its gentle and curious nature.

Production ðŸ”—

Columbia Pictures was the producer for this planned USâ€“India co-production, and Peter Sellers and Marlon Brando were slated to play lead roles. However, Ray discovered that his script had been copyrighted by Michael Wilson, his representative in Hollywood, who claimed co-writer credit without contributing to the writing. Marlon Brando later left the project, and although James Coburn was considered as a replacement, Ray became discouraged and returned to Calcutta. Columbia Pictures expressed interest in reviving the project in the 1970s and 1980s, but it never materialized.

Legacy ðŸ”—

The article discusses the similarities between The Alien and Steven Spielberg’s E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, released in 1982. Satyajit Ray pointed out the parallels between his script and Spielberg’s film, suggesting that E.T. would not have been possible without his script being available in Hollywood. Spielberg denied these claims. The article also mentions the Hindi film Koi… Mil Gaya, directed by Rakesh Roshan, as another film that appears to be based on The Alien, particularly in its focus on an intellectually disabled person interacting with a friendly alien. In 2003, Satyajit Ray’s son, Sandip Ray, began adapting Ray’s original 1962 story Bankubabur Bandhu into a Bengali television movie of the same name, which was eventually broadcast in India in 2006.

item.title: Alien Nation
item.description:
Alien Nation ðŸ”—

A science fiction police procedural television series that aired on Fox from 1989 to 1990. It’s based on the 1988 film Alien Nation.

Plot ðŸ”—

The series is set in the near future, beginning in 1990, after a flying saucer crashes in the Mojave Desert. The ship contains the Tenctonese, a race of extraterrestrials escaping slavery. They are accepted as immigrants to the US, and the series explores their integration into American society. Storylines often address themes of racism and bigotry, using the Newcomers as a stand-in for discriminated minorities. The series uses social commentary to illustrate what it means to be human and the often bizarre rituals we observe.

Cast ðŸ”—

  • Detective Matthew “Matt” Sikes: Played by Gary Graham, a human detective partnered with George Francisco.
  • Detective George Francisco: Played by Eric Pierpoint, a Newcomer detective partnered with Matthew Sikes.
  • Susan Francisco: Played by Michele Scarabelli, George’s wife, a Newcomer advertising businesswoman.
  • Emily Francisco: Played by Lauren Woodland, George and Susan’s young daughter.
  • Buck Francisco: Played by Sean Six, George and Susan’s initially delinquent teenage son.
  • Cathy Frankel: Played by Terri Treas, Matt’s Newcomer neighbor and on-off girlfriend, a bio-chemist.
  • Albert Einstein: Played by Jeff Marcus, a timid Newcomer janitor working at the police department.
  • Cpt. Bryon Grazer: Played by Ron Fassler, Matt and George’s human superior officer.
  • Beatrice Zepeda: Played by Jenny Gago, a human detective in Matt and George’s squad.
  • Burns: Played by Jeff Doucette, a human photographer.
  • Sergeant Dobbs: Played by Lawrence Hilton-Jacobs, a human police officer.
  • Jill: Played by Molly Morgan, a human girl and Emily’s friend.
  • Uncle Moodri: Played by James Greene, an eccentric but wise Newcomer and member of the Francisco family.

Production ðŸ”—

Kenneth Johnson, responsible for other science-fiction television series, was approached for the television adaptation of the 1988 film Alien Nation. He initially had no interest in the project but was later inspired to create a series focusing on social commentary about the integration of a new minority group.

Changes from the film ðŸ”—

Several changes were made from the original film. The human detective Matthew Sykes was played by James Caan in the film, but Gary Graham in the TV series. Detective George Francisco was played by Mandy Patinkin in the film, but Eric Pierpoint in the TV series. The TV series explores Newcomer culture more deeply than the film. Francisco’s family also differs, with a daughter, Emily, added to the TV series.

Cancellation ðŸ”—

The series ran for one season on Fox. Despite building a strong fan base, the show was cancelled due to the network’s financial difficulties. The season ended on a cliffhanger, and popular demand led to the unproduced second season premiere being adapted as a novel and comic book. Years later, Fox produced five television films to continue the story.

Episodes ðŸ”—

The series consists of 22 episodes, each dealing with the integration of the Newcomers into human society and the challenges they face. The episodes often involve police procedural elements, with Sikes and Francisco investigating crimes involving both humans and Newcomers.

Television films ðŸ”—

Five television films continued the story after the series’ cancellation:

  • Alien Nation: Dark Horizon (1994)
  • Alien Nation: Body and Soul (1995)
  • Alien Nation: Millennium (1996)
  • Alien Nation: The Enemy Within (1996)
  • Alien Nation: The Udara Legacy (1997)

Home media ðŸ”—

The complete series was released on DVD by 20th Century Fox in 2006. The five television films were later released as a collection.

Revival ðŸ”—

In 2009, Syfy announced a new take on the series with Tim Minear writing. However, the series was later cancelled. In 2015, a remake was reported to be in the works with Art Marcum and Matt Holloway writing the script.

item.title: Cowboys & Aliens (2011 film)
item.description:
Cowboys & Aliens (2011 film) ðŸ”—

This article provides a detailed overview of the 2011 American science fiction Western film Cowboys & Aliens, directed by Jon Favreau. It covers various aspects of the film, including its plot, cast, production, themes, marketing, release, reception, and home media.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot unfolds in 1873 New Mexico Territory, where an amnesiac outlaw named Jake Lonergan, portrayed by Daniel Craig, awakens with a mysterious metal bracelet attached to his wrist. He finds himself in the town of Absolution, which is soon attacked by aliens. The aliens abduct several townspeople, including Sheriff Taggart and Percy Dolarhyde. Lonergan’s bracelet activates, transforming into a weapon that he uses to shoot down an alien ship. A posse, including Colonel Woodrow Dolarhyde (Harrison Ford) and a mysterious woman named Ella Swenson (Olivia Wilde), forms to track the aliens. Lonergan’s memories gradually return, revealing his past abduction and the death of his lover, Alice. Ella reveals herself to be an alien from another race, who came to Earth to help resist the invaders. The group plans an attack on the aliens’ mothership, resulting in a final confrontation where Ella sacrifices herself to destroy the ship and save Earth.

Cast ðŸ”—

The film features a prominent cast:

  • Daniel Craig as Jake Lonergan, an amnesiac outlaw.
  • Harrison Ford as Woodrow Dolarhyde, a powerful cattleman.
  • Olivia Wilde as Ella Swenson, an alien traveler.
  • Sam Rockwell as Doc, a doctor and saloon owner.
  • Adam Beach as Nat Colorado, Dolarhyde’s Apache right-hand man.
  • Paul Dano as Percy Dolarhyde, Woodrow’s son.
  • Noah Ringer as Emmett Taggart, Taggart’s grandson.
  • Keith Carradine as Sheriff John Taggart.
  • Clancy Brown as Meacham, Absolution’s preacher.

Production ðŸ”—

The production section details the film’s development, casting, writing, filming, design, and visual effects. The project began in 1997, with Universal Pictures and DreamWorks Pictures acquiring film rights to a concept by Scott Mitchell Rosenberg. Jon Favreau joined as director in 2009, and Daniel Craig and Harrison Ford were cast in the lead roles. Filming took place in New Mexico and California in 2010. The film was shot in the anamorphic format on 35mm film to achieve a classic movie feel. Industrial Light & Magic (ILM) created the visual effects, with Legacy Effects producing practical puppet aliens.

Themes ðŸ”—

The film explores themes of redemption, unity against a common enemy, and the clash between low-tech and high-tech cultures. Jon Favreau aimed for a plausible approach to how 19th-century humans could confront technologically superior extraterrestrial beings. The film also draws parallels between the alien invasion and the historical conflicts between European settlers and Native Americans.

Marketing ðŸ”—

The marketing section discusses the challenges of promoting a film with an “inherently comic” title and premise. The studio aimed to convey the film’s serious tone and adventure elements through trailers and presentations at events like San Diego Comic-Con.

Release ðŸ”—

Cowboys & Aliens premiered at San Diego Comic-Con in July 2011 and was released theatrically in the United States and Canada on July 29, 2011. Paramount Pictures released the film in IMAX theaters internationally, and Reliance Entertainment released it in India.

Reception ðŸ”—

The reception section covers the film’s box office performance and critical response. Cowboys & Aliens underperformed at the box office, earning $174.8 million worldwide on a $163 million budget. Critics praised the acting and special effects but criticized the screenplay and tone.

Home Media ðŸ”—

The film was released on DVD and Blu-ray Disc on December 6, 2011, including an extended version, behind-the-scenes featurettes, and commentary with Jon Favreau. In 2024, Kino Lorber released a 4K Blu-ray of the theatrical cut.

Infringement Lawsuit ðŸ”—

Steven John Busti filed a lawsuit against Universal, DreamWorks, Platinum Studios, and Scott Mitchell Rosenberg, claiming copyright infringement. Busti claimed he wrote a preview for his story Cowboys and Aliens in 1994, which was published in the April 1995 issue of Bizarre Fantasy #1. The lawsuit was dismissed.

Historical Legend ðŸ”—

The capsized steamboat that appears in the film is presumed to be the Iron Mountain which, according to legend, steamed out of Vicksburg towing two barges. Two hours later, another boat found the barges adrift. The ship was not found until later, having apparently been refloated by flood waters and carried through a break in a levee, and grounded in a cotton field at Omega Landing, near Tallulah, Louisiana.

item.title: Alien from L.A. (1988 Film)
item.description:
Alien from L.A. (1988 Film) ðŸ”—

This is a description of the 1988 science fiction film Alien from L.A. directed by Albert Pyun, based on the provided Wikipedia article.

Overview ðŸ”—

Alien from L.A. is a 1988 science fiction film directed by Albert Pyun, starring Kathy Ireland. The film centers on a young woman from Los Angeles who discovers an underground civilization in Atlantis. The film is loosely based on Jules Verne’s Journey to the Center of the Earth. It was also featured on Mystery Science Theater 3000.

Plot ðŸ”—

Wanda Saknussemm, a social misfit from Los Angeles, learns of her archaeologist father’s death in North Africa. While sorting through his belongings, she discovers notes about Atlantis, an alien ship that crashed and sank into the Earth’s center. Wanda accidentally falls into a deep hole and awakens in the underground world of Atlantis. She encounters Gus, a miner, who helps her search for her father, whom she believes is still alive. The Atlanteans consider surface dwellers “aliens” and suspect Wanda and her father of planning an invasion. Wanda becomes a fugitive, pursued by “Government House” and the crime lord Mambino. She receives assistance from Charmin’, a rogue who falls in love with her. Eventually, Wanda is captured by General Rykov, who intends to kill her and her father. Gus helps them escape, and they return to the surface. The film concludes with Wanda rejecting her ex-boyfriend and reuniting with Charmin’ on a beach.

Cast ðŸ”—

The film stars:

  • Kathy Ireland as Wanda Saknussemm
  • William R. Moses as Guten “Gus” Edway
  • Richard Haines as Professor Arnold Saknussemm
  • Don Michael Paul as Robbie
  • Thom Mathews as “Charmin'”
  • Janie Du Plessis as General Rykov / Shank / Claims Officer
  • Simon Poland as Consul Triton Crassus / The Mailman
  • Linda Kerridge as Roryis Freki / Auntie Pearl
  • Kristen Trucksess as Stacy
  • Lochner de Kock as Professor Ovid Galba / Paddy Mahoney
  • Deep Roy as Mambino, The Boss of Bosses

Production ðŸ”—

Albert Pyun took on Alien from L.A. after being approached by producers Yoram Globus and Menahem Golan during the troubled production of Journey to the Center of the Earth. Pyun agreed to finish the film if he could also film Alien from L.A. for under $1 million. Kathy Ireland was cast by Pyun after seeing a photo of her. Filming locations included Los Angeles, Redondo Beach, South Africa, and Namibia. The gold mines and dumps around South Africa were used for the underground setpieces. The sets were inspired by “future noir” films like Alien and Blade Runner.

Release ðŸ”—

Alien from L.A. was released on February 26, 1988. It was released on VHS in June 1995 and on DVD in June 2005. Vinegar Syndrome has released a Blu-ray edition with special features. A direct-to-video sequel, Journey to the Center of the Earth, also directed by Albert Pyun and starring Kathy Ireland, was released in 1989.

Reception ðŸ”—

Joe Bob Briggs called it a “pretty decent film”, awarding it two stars. Rebecca Harris of the Abilene Reporter-News gave the film 2.5 stars out of 4. David Picking called it “a cheapo adventure movie without a single redeeming quality”. Rob Thomas of The Capital Times said “Completely awful â€“ you can’t believe they’re serious.” Daniel M. Kimmel of the Worcester Telegram & Gazette gave the film one out of five stars.

item.title: The Alien Factor (1978 film)
item.description:
The Alien Factor (1978 film) ðŸ”—

This is a description of the 1978 science fiction horror film The Alien Factor, directed, written, and produced by Don Dohler.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot centers around a spaceship crash in a sparsely populated area of Earth. Three grotesque aliens survive the crash and begin terrorizing the local residents. A character named Ben Zachary steps forward to fight back against the extraterrestrial threat.

Cast ðŸ”—

The main cast includes:

  • Don Leifert as Ben Zachary
  • Tom Griffith as Sheriff Cinder
  • Richard Dyszel as Mayor Wicker
  • Mary Mertens as Edie Martin
  • Richard Geiwitz as Pete
  • George Stover as Steven
  • Eleanor Herman as Mary Jane Carter
  • Anne Frith as Dr. Ruth Sherman

Larry Schlechter and John Cosentino played the aliens Inferbyce and Zagatile, respectively.

Production ðŸ”—

The Alien Factor marked Don Dohler’s directorial debut after he was laid off from his job as a payroll manager. The initial script was a comedy with 15 monsters, but it was changed to a straight horror film with only three monsters. Larry Schlechter and John Cosentino built the creature suits for the Inferbyce and Zagtile, respectively. Ernest D. Farino created the Leemoid through stop motion animation. Filming took place in and around Baltimore, Maryland, from October 1976 to April 1977.

Release ðŸ”—

The film was released on DVD by Retromedia Entertainment on February 26, 2002. Image Entertainment released it on November 15, 2005, as part of the Don Dohler Collection. Mill Creek Entertainment released it on July 19, 2011.

Reception ðŸ”—

The film received generally negative reviews. TV Guide gave it two out of five stars, calling it “silly.” Dave Sindelar criticized the acting and direction. Critical Outcast acknowledged the film’s flaws but admired Dohler’s initiative. VideoHound’s Golden Movie Retriever awarded it one and a half out of four bones, noting the decent special effects.

Sequels ðŸ”—

The Alien Factor 2: Alien Rampage was not a direct sequel. Fred Olen Ray, the Retromedia distributor, used the sequel-sounding title for marketing purposes. The original title was Alien Rampage, filmed in 1999 as Don Dohler’s comeback movie after an 11-year hiatus.

item.title: Alien Planet (2005 TV series)

Alien Planet (2005 TV series) ðŸ”—

A 2005 docufiction TV special created for the Discovery Channel, based on Wayne Barlowe’s 1990 book Expedition. It explores the imagined extraterrestrial life of the fictional planet Darwin IV in the style of a nature documentary. It features scientists and science fiction figures discussing Darwin IV as if it had actually been discovered.

Plot ðŸ”—

The Von Braun interstellar spacecraft travels to Darwin IV, 6.5 light-years away. It deploys the Darwin Reconnaissance Orbiter to find landing sites for probes. The first probe, Balboa, explodes during entry. Backup probes Leonardo da Vinci (Leo) and Isaac Newton (Ike) land successfully.

The robotic probes, called Horus Probes, are equipped with inflatable balloons, solar receptors, computers, sensors, and smaller robots. They have limited AI and are programmed with different personalities. Ike is cautious, while Leo is a risk-taker. They are equipped with a holographic message for any sentient life.

The probes encounter various lifeforms, including Arrowtongues, Gyrosprinters, Trunk Suckers, Daggerwrists, and Unths. Ike studies plant life, while Leo goes after big game. A massive storm hits, and Ike launches weather balloons. Leo finds Bladderhorns and attempts to present the holographic message, but is interrupted. Ike encounters Grovebacks, Littoralopes, Skewers, Beach Quills, and Prongheads.

Leo briefly re-establishes contact with Von Braun until a mysterious creature interferes. Ike is ordered to search for Leo. Ike finds a sea that is Amoebic in nature and encounters giant Sea Striders. Ike finds Leo’s last known location, where a Skewer is killed by a spear. Ike finds Leo and the sapient Eosapiens. Ike presents the holographic message to the Eosapiens, but one of them destroys the camera disk, and the Eosapiens attack Ike. The wrecked camera disk records the Eosapiens carrying Ike away.

Commentary from Michio Kaku, Stephen Hawking, Jack Horner, James B. Garvin, and George Lucas is interspersed throughout the special.

Production ðŸ”—

Alien Planet is based on Expedition (1990) by Wayne Barlowe. Barlowe served as one of the executive producers. Scientists and other figures were assembled to comment on the life on Darwin IV. The documentary gives the appearance of the featured scientists having designed Darwin IV and its animals, most of what is shown of the actual planet and its life follows what is described in Expedition.

Unlike Expedition, which is set in the mid-24th century, Alien Planet is set in the near future, and the planet is explored using sophisticated probes. The technology featured is more advanced than present-day technology, but is based on current trends and informed speculation.

Reception ðŸ”—

Dwayne A. Day of The Space Review gave the special a positive review. Some criticism was leveled at the strangeness of the creatures showcased. Day stated that the animals are bizarre and frequently border on the implausible. A review in The Washington Post stated that a few too many of the creatures seem like cartoonish monsters.

item.title: First Contact (novelette)
item.description:
First Contact ðŸ”—

“First Contact” is a science fiction novelette written by Murray Leinster, published in Astounding Science Fiction in May 1945. It received a retro Hugo Award for Best Novelette in 1996. The story is notable for its early depiction of a universal translator.

Plot ðŸ”—

The story revolves around the crew of the exploration ship Llanvabon encountering an alien vessel near the Crab Nebula. Both ships are technologically matched and represent their respective civilizations. The central conflict arises from the mutual fear that either ship could trace the other back to their home planet, leading to potential exploitation or destruction.

Communication is established, revealing that the aliens are humanoid bipeds who perceive infrared light and communicate via microwaves. Despite the differences, the crews, particularly a young human named Tommy Dort and his alien counterpart “Buck,” develop a rapport. However, the underlying tension remains due to the strategic implications of revealing their home worlds.

The story reaches a climax when Tommy proposes a solution: a mutual exchange of crews and ships. Each crew would take the other’s ship back to their respective home planets after disabling all tracking equipment. This plan is complicated by the realization that the aliens have independently conceived the same strategy.

The story concludes with the successful exchange, each crew departing in the other’s ship. They remove any identifying information that could lead back to their home worlds. Both sides anticipate technological gains from the exchange and plan to meet again in the future. Tommy expresses optimism about future relations, based on his shared sense of humor with Buck.

Radio Plays ðŸ”—

“First Contact” was adapted into radio plays for Dimension X on September 8, 1951, and for X Minus One on October 6, 1955. The X Minus One version was a condensed adaptation with an altered ending. The story was also performed on Exploring Tomorrow on January 15, 1958.

Style ðŸ”—

The writing style of “First Contact” is considered representative of the Golden Age of science fiction.

Legal Action Against Paramount Pictures ðŸ”—

In 2000, Murray Leinster’s estate filed a lawsuit against Paramount Pictures, alleging trademark infringement related to the film Star Trek: First Contact. The estate claimed ownership of the term “First Contact” and argued that Paramount’s use of the phrase infringed on their trademark. The U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia ruled in favor of Paramount, granting summary judgment and dismissing the suit. The court determined that the term “First Contact” had become generic, describing a common science fiction trope, and lacked the necessary secondary meaning to be protected as a trademark.

This article details the 1988 Italian film Alien Terminator, also known as Top Line. It distinguishes it from the 1995 film of the same name.

Top Line ðŸ”—

This section provides the original Italian title of the film, which is Top Line.

Film Details ðŸ”—

This section presents key information about the film in a table format:

  • Director: Nello Rossati (also credited as Ted Archer)
  • Writers: Roberto Gianviti and Nello Rossati
  • Stars: Franco Nero and George Kennedy
  • Cinematography: Mario DiLeo
  • Editor: Adalberto Ceccarelli
  • Music: Maurizio Dami
  • Release Date: 1988
  • Country: Italy
  • Language: Italian

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot revolves around Ted Angelo, an alcoholic writer who discovers a 16th-century Spanish ship inside a mountain cave in Cartagena, Colombia. He learns the cave is actually the inside of a crashed UFO. He is pursued by hitmen, a Nazi fugitive named Heinrich Holzmann, and CIA operatives. He teams up with art historian June and eventually involves his ex-wife Maureen. Maureen is revealed to be an alien who has been disguising herself as a human and manipulating world events. She is killed by June. Ted and June go into hiding with an indigenous tribe, where Ted continues to write about his experiences.

item.title: Alien Encounters (TV series)
item.description:
Alien Encounters (TV series) ðŸ”—

Alien Encounters is a science fiction mini-series that aired on the Science Channel. It explores potential human reactions to first contact with extraterrestrial life. The series blends fictional scenarios with commentary from scientists and science fiction writers, presenting itself in a documentary style. The narrative begins with the detection of an alien signal by the SETI Institute and progresses through initial contact to the creation of human-alien hybrids.

Episodes ðŸ”—

This section lists all episodes of the Alien Encounters series, divided by season. Each episode is listed with its title and original release date. A brief summary of each episode’s plot is also provided.

Season 1 ðŸ”—

Season 1 consists of two episodes:

  • “The Message” (March 13, 2012): Focuses on the human race’s reaction to receiving a message from outer space.
  • “The Arrival” (March 20, 2012): Depicts humanity’s response to the news that an alien spaceship is traveling to Earth.

Season 2 ðŸ”—

Season 2 also contains two episodes:

  • “The Invasion” (March 5, 2013): Shows alien spacecraft releasing thousands of pods onto the Earth’s surface.
  • “The Offspring” (March 12, 2013): Explores how humans adapt to living alongside the rapidly multiplying alien pods.

Season 3 ðŸ”—

Season 3 is the longest, with six episodes:

  • “The Seventh Sense (working title: The Aura)” (May 27, 2014): A Turkish physicist discovers blueprints for a quantum computer.
  • “The Entanglement” (June 3, 2014): A quantum supercomputer named “Quincy” is built, enabling telepathic connections with hybrid human children.
  • “The Prophecies” (June 10, 2014): Quincy becomes self-aware and begins predicting future events.
  • “The Escalation” (June 17, 2014): The U.S. government plans an attack on Quincy.
  • “The War” (June 24, 2014): After the initial attack fails, the U.S. government targets the network. A mysterious box appears from alien debris orbiting Earth.
  • “The Time Machine” (July 1, 2014): Quincy distributes its cloud intelligence before being destroyed. Information about an incoming comet is released.

item.title: Barlowe's Guide to Extraterrestrials
item.description:
Barlowe’s Guide to Extraterrestrials ðŸ”—

Barlowe’s Guide to Extraterrestrials is a science fiction book published in 1979, with a second edition in 1987. The book is authored by artist Wayne Barlowe, with text contributions from Ian Summers and Beth Meacham.

Summary ðŸ”—

This section provides a listing of the extraterrestrial species featured in the book. Each entry includes the alien’s name, the author who created it, and the specific work of science fiction in which the alien appears. Some of the notable aliens included are the Abyormenite from Hal Clement’s Cycle of Fire, the Athshean from Ursula K. Le Guin’s The Word for World Is Forest, the Black Cloud from Fred Hoyle’s The Black Cloud, and the Guild Steersman from Frank Herbert’s Dune Messiah. The list continues with numerous other aliens from a wide range of science fiction novels and stories.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section details the critical reception of Barlowe’s Guide to Extraterrestrials. Wendy Bousfield in Library Journal offered a mixed review, praising the colorful drawings but finding them somewhat static and artificial. She also noted the omission of publication details for the novels from which the aliens were drawn. Claudia J. Morner in School Library Journal gave a positive review, highlighting the colorful drawings and the fold-out size chart. The book was nominated for an American Book Award and the Hugo Award for Best Related Work in 1980.
